Award.AbstractNarration:
Cognitive ability is strongly associated with many important life outcomes, including longevity, physical health, well-being, employment, job success, and educational attainment. Although research recognizes the importance of cognitive ability, both the United States and the greater international research community still lack the accessible and dynamic cognitive ability measures needed to help advance cognitive science research and assessment. Thus, the fundamental goal of this research is to develop a bank of public domain cognitive ability measures for use in a wide variety of contexts, both applied and theoretical. This public domain and open-source tool, the International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR), will be developed by an international consortium of researchers. This award supports the US portion of this international research consortium.

ICAR is a framework for international collaboration between the US and researchers in Germany and the UK and has been structured to allow additional international collaborators to participate. By encouraging the use, revision, and ongoing development of ICAR measures among qualified research groups around the world, ICAR will further our understanding of the structure of cognitive abilities as well as the nature of associations between cognitive ability constructs and important life outcomes. ICAR researchers will develop open-source computer packages that will facilitate the automatic generation and dissemination of large item sets. These item sets will provide scholars around the world with a dynamic platform that is not restricted by proprietary interests.

The development of ICAR will benefit from the expertise of each of the three psychometric research groups. These teams bring unique skills to the project including prior experience with automatic item generation, online administration of cognitive ability measures to large samples, and computer adaptive testing in online environments.

The broader impacts of this project include working toward broader inclusion of cognitive ability assessment in social sciences research generally; more tailored treatment of physical and mental health issues based on cognitive ability assessments designed to gauge patients' capacity for self-care; and a better understanding of the ways in which cognitive abilities change over the lifespan, including study of the factors which exacerbate or protect against cognitive aging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Individual differences in ability, temperament, and interests have long been known to be associated with success in the sciences and other occupations. In particular, the assessment of cognitive ability is important for selection and training in the sciences, humanities, and in business. Unfortunately, the study of individual differences in cognitive ability has been limited by the need to use proprietary instruments. This has limited the study of ability to a small number of labs able to afford the proprietary instruments and has led to a specialization of intelligence studies to large scale educational research projects. The International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR) project was designed to address these issues by developing a public-domain and open source tool to measure cognitive ability in a variety of applications.

This project was an international consortium (including colleagues in the UK and Germany) to develop, validate and disseminate open source measures of cognitive ability. 12 ability measures reflecting over 900 new items were developed and presented to random subsets of 221,000 participants. Using an innovative procedure for presenting subsets of items selected from a much larger item pool, we were able to validate the structure of 952 items, even though each participant responded to only about 15-20 items. The Synthetic Aperture Personality Assessment (aka SAPA) procedure presents random subsets of items taken from a larger item bank. Because the items have a Massively Missing Completely at Random (MMCAR) structure, inferences about the structure of the entire data matrix may be made from synthetically formed correlations.

In an extension of prior work, we developed new items measuring the ability to do two and three dimensional mental rotations, to solve figural analogies, including a variation on a proprietary test, the Raven’s Progressive Matrices, another matrix reasoning test, verbal skills including propositional reasoning, a new way of measuring remote associates, several hundred arithmetical reasoning items, and the ability to detect emotions from faces. With the exception of the facial emotion task, the various measures showed a clear hierarchical structure (see figure 1) with a general factor of ability accounting from 60-80% of the total variability. Each of the separate item types were internally consistent and had good statistical properties.

Computerized procedures for generating multiple items within each item type (Automatic Item Generation or AIG algorithms) were developed which will allow other researchers to create new items within the validated structure of the ICAR. The software package, psych,  for the open source statistical system, R, was further refined as part of this project.

Web pages to present, report, and share the various item types were developed and will continue to be maintained. The SAPA-project web site will continue to collect ICAR data and integrate them with measures of interests and temperament. As we have done in the past, data will be shared at such platforms as DataVerse.
